docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush told older residents in Florida today that his plans for changing Medicare and providing prescription drug benefits would give them control over their health care, while Vice President Al Gore would give them only ''a government-run'' health maintenance organization. ''Seems like to me we need to trust seniors to be able to tailor a plan to meet each person's needs,'' Mr. Bush said during a town hall-style meeting at a large retirement complex early this afternoon in Clearwater, near Tampa. ''The federal government ought to be humble enough to allow you to make choices.''

headline.main: Bush Pushes Health Plan To Attract Older Voters

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush presses efforts to attract older voters by telling aging residents of Clearwater, Fla, that his plans for changing Medicare and providing prescription drug benefits would give them control over their health care, while Al Gore's would give them only government-run health maintenance organization; move underscores threat he suddenly faces from Gore; although aides previously talked of Florida as almost certain Republican win, recent polls classify it as toss-up; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy-Ann Min DeParle, administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, the federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, announced today that she was resigning on Oct. 1 to take a temporary job teaching at Harvard University. Ms. DeParle said she would become a fellow at the Institute of Politics, which is affiliated with the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.

headline.main: Director of Medicare Will Quit For a Teaching Job at Harvard

docs.lead_paragraph: The Eastchester Town Board has voted 5 to 0 to offer health benefits to same-sex domestic partners of town employees. The action came after the board heard protests and support for the measure. ''We saw it as an issue of treating all employees the same,'' Town Supervisor James E. Cavanaugh said. ''We didn't mean it to be a social crusade.'' The benefits were requested by Teamsters Local 456, which represents the police force, and they apply to all 200 full-time town employees. No other municipality in the county offers the benefits, though the county, state, and New York City governments do. Robert Worth
docs.abstract: Town Board in Eastchester, NY, votes, 5 to 0, to offer health benefits to same-sex domestic partners of town employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Democratic Party looked for Congressional seats it could pick up in the November elections, the one held by Senator Rod Grams of Minnesota was high on the list. Senator Grams, a conservative Republican in a state with a large liberal bent, has made few legislative splashes in his one term in the Senate, and his approval rating has been notably low.
docs.abstract: Minnesota Democrats have been unable to unify around any of four major candidates for US Senate, who hope to unseat vulnerable Republican freshman Sen Rod Grams, whose approval rating has been notably low; prospects of winning Senate seat seem less certain; candidates--Rebecca Yanisch, Mike Ciresi, state senator Jerry Janezich, Mark Dayton--are spending campaign resources battling each other instead of Grams in late season primary; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Quest for the Grail Q. For my sister's 30th birthday, I would like to take her on a King Arthur tour of England, since this is one of her interests. Do any tour companies, American or English, offer such a program? -- Amy Hoddick, Pasadena, Calif. A. A number of companies will squire you around southwest England in search of King Arthur, with prices ranging from the princely to the pedestrian.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bad news about the detailed economic plan the Gore-Lieberman campaign released last week is that it does contain some smoke and mirrors. The good news is that the smoke and mirrors are there not to conceal the true cost of extravagant promises, but to make a modest, not particularly exciting plan sound like something more. Never mind those 192 pages of good intentions. There are really only two important components to the plan: an extension of Medicare, mainly to provide prescription drug coverage; and ''targeted tax cuts,'' tax breaks that reward families for all sorts of good behavior.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column criticizes complexity of Vice Pres Al Gore's tax proposals and his eagerness to cut taxes in the first place (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sara Ann Echaniz and Dr. Peter Carl Krause were married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard. Nicholas Basden, a friend of the couple who was appointed a Massachusetts civil marriage celebrant for the day, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents in Chilmark, Mass. The couple, both 33, graduated from Harvard.

docs.lead_paragraph: I moved to Brooklyn 15 years ago and have since spent several mornings each week walking, running or just greeting the day in Prospect Park. In recent years, these tranquil mornings have been too often disrupted by snarling dogs who are permitted off their leashes in the early morning during what the park system refers to as ''courtesy hours.'' In the last year alone, I have been cornered four times by ill-behaved dogs -- two of them pit bulls -- who were clearly unfit to run loose in a public park. The owners of such dogs rarely apologize and sometimes behave as belligerently as their animals. The owner of a big, menacing boxer promised to kill me when I told him I would mace the dog if it charged me again. A few weeks later, the owner of a frothing German shepherd declined to leash his dog -- essentially using it to corner me, while he advised me to stay home during ''courtesy hours'' and lectured me on the dog's right to be free.

headline.main: Editorial Observer; When Dogs Are More Important Than People

docs.abstract: Brent Staples Editorial Observer column scores dog owners in New York City who do not respect the rights of others in public spaces, particularly the parks (M)
